Gurugram: Four cops booked for escape of.description: GURUGRAM: A day after a Bhondsi jail inmate escaped from Civil hospital in Sector 10, the police department has booked four of its officers, who were posted at the hospital, when the accused fled. Police sources said the accused — Haji Ayub — was recently nabbed by a team from civil lines police station for his alleged involvement in a 2017 cheating and fraud case. “Haji was produced in court and sent to Bhondsi jail. After reaching the jail, Haji — who is a diabetic — complained of illness. He was admitted at the civil hosipital on June 15, where he was undergoing treatment,” an officer said. On Monday, Haji’s daughter came to meet him and soon after she left, he asked the policemen to take him to the washroom. “He locked the door from inside and fled after breaking the window,” an officer said. An FIR was registered under sections 120B (criminal conspiracy), 223 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 224 (causing hurt) of the IPC against Haji, his daughter and head constable Krishan, constables Rajiv, Sandeep and Narendra. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. 20 DLF-4 homes on government\u2019s rada.description: GURUGRAM: As many as 20 homes constructed in an upscale area of the city are under the scanner of the city authorities for illegal construction. Developer DLF has written to the department of town and country planning (DTCP), deputy commissioner and MCG, alleging that several plot owners in DLF-4 had carried out illegal constructions. The developer also claimed plot owners are constructing buildings with more than five floors, violating the rules. As per the norms, owners cannot construct buildings with more than four floors on an individual plot. Till now, DLF has submitted a list of around 850 such plots in different phases of DLF and the DTCP had sealed nearly three dozen houses on Golf Course Road recently. The plot owners, it has been alleged, build additional floors after getting occupation certificates from DTCP. In some cases, the buildings constructed for residential purposes are used for commercial activities in violation of the rules. “We would like to bring to your notice that some plot owners are illegally constructing their houses beyond sanctioned plan,” said DLF in its letter to the authorities. “Such illegal constructions put additional burden on the existing infrastructure like sewerage, drainage, road and power supply of the colonies causing inconvenience to other residents,” said a resident of DLF-4, adding that in some of these cases people have turned homes into commercial units, causing nuisance in the area. In most cases, these buildings are used for setting up guesthouses and in some other cases, they have leased out buildings to app-based accommodation facilities. Senior town planner (STP) Sudhir Chouhan said DTCP is issuing notices regularly and sealing drives have been conducted, but plot owners go to court and manage to get stay. “It obstructs our drive. Still the department is pursuing it. Courts are ordering stay even without giving us chance to put forth our views,” said Chouhan. He also said the DTCP is empowered to take action under Urban Area Act 1975 in the municipal limit. However, courts grant stay in contravention of the Act’s Section 3B. Chouhan said he had been in the court personally to take up the issue. The department, he said, is now planning to approach the apex court on this matter. As per the Section 3B of Haryana Development And Regulation of Urban Areas Act, 1975, no person is allowed to carry out constructions violating the approved plan. If they carry out construction in violation of approved plan, they will face action from the department. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

FIR filed in Gurugram metro station hara.description: GURUGRAM: An FIR has been lodged against an unidentified man for stalking and sexually harassing a 29-year-old woman executive at Huda City Centre metro station on Friday. TOI reported about the case on Tuesday. Police have registered a complaint under IPC sections 354A (sexual harassment) and 506 (criminal intimidation). According to ACP crime, Shamsher Singh, the woman, who is yet to file a written complaint, has been requested to record a statement. “We have registered a complaint against an unidentified man and we are currently trying to identify and locate the accused. We are looking at the CCTV feed from the spot,” said Singh. On Friday night, the woman was allegedly harassed by a man in his 20s when she was walking towards the exit at the Huda City Centre metro station. She told TOI that the man stood in front of her and masturbated, and when she confronted him and slapped him, he screamed at her. She further said no one had come to her rescue. The woman had written to Gurugram Police on Facebook Messenger on Friday itself with details of the incident. However, when she did not get a response till Monday, she took to Twitter to share her ordeal. She also reached out to DMRC and identified the accused in the CCTV feeds provided by them on Sunday. “I want to file a complaint and pursue this case because it is time we start speaking about the need for safe spaces for women,” she told TOI. “But at the same time, I am scared about my own safety.” Police’s delayed response has only made those apprehensions worse. The woman is originally a resident of Delhi but moved to Gurugram as she works there. The incident, she says, may have a disruptive effect on her life as she fears she might now be forced to move back to Delhi. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Metro flasher is a courier with Cyber Ci.description: GURUGRAM: Dinesh, the 25-year-old man accused of flashing a woman and masturbating at Huda City Centre metro station last Friday, was sent to judicial custody by a local court on Thursday, a day after his arrest by the special cell of Delhi Police. Police said they had collected the clothes he was wearing that day as well as his bag for forensic tests. Metro CCTV footage, with the help of which the woman identified him, is also with investigators now.  Dinesh, a resident of Sushant Lok 2, has been charged under sections 354A (sexual harassment) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of the IPC. Dinesh, police sources said, is a ‘dak runner’ (who carries official documents to and from various offices). For the past year, he has been associated with a co-working establishment in Cyber City, investigators said. He has no criminal record and is originally from Maudaha in Hamirpur district of UP. He lives with other family members in an EWS (economically weaker section) flat near MKM Market in Sector 57. His father works as a cleaner and office boy at a wellknown real estate developer’s office in the city. Dinesh is not married. A job from the co-working facility had taken Dinesh to an office at Ashram Marg on June 14, the day of the incident. He boarded the metro at INA and got off at Huda City Centre. While coming out of the metro station, he started watching porn on his mobile, a police officer said. On the escalator that brings passengers to the station complex’s compound, he masturbated while he was standing right behind the woman, a 29-year-old brand manager at a Gurugram-based firm.  She raised an alarm, confronted Dinesh and slapped him. Dinesh retorted with abuses and fled. It was around 9.25pm when this happened. Police began the investigation only on Monday, after she shared her experience on Twitter. She also told TOI her ordeal underscored the urgent need for measures to make public spaces safer. She had also said she was determined to pursue the case. An FIR was registered at metro police station and ACP (crime against women) Usha Kundu was put in charge of the investigation. The woman has already recorded a statement before a magistrate. It was Delhi Police, though, that made the arrest. “We were tracking the accused and a team reached Lodhi Garden when people informed one person was picked up by police. Many teams were working, so we thought any of our teams might have taken him. But later, we got to know he was picked up by the special cell of Delhi Police,” said a Gurugram police officer. Journalists\u2019 bail plea rejected in.description: NOIDA: A fast-track court on Wednesday rejected the bail plea by three staffers of a Noida-based TV news channel — who were arrested by Noida Police for airing a show that was deemed defamatory to chief minister Yogi Adityanath — in the second case against them, a day after a sessions court had granted them bail in the first case. The arguments raised by the trio during their hearing in the second case, which pertains to cheating and forgery, were “subject to investigation”. Without commenting on the nature of the case, the court of Ved Prakash Verma, ADJ (fast-track court), said sufficient grounds for bail were not there. The lawyer of Ishika Singh, owner of BR Media Services Private Limited, contended that Bharat Hydel Projects Private Limited (owner of TV channel Network 10, also known as Nation Live) had a content-sharing agreement with her firm, signed on February 14 this year. K K Singh, the lawyer, argued that his client had been framed, that her firm had a valid content-sharing agreement with owners of Network 10, as well as a “time slot” for running content on the channel, whose logo was retained. K K Singh told TOI they will now move Allahabad high court for bail. Advocate Nitin Gupta, representing the other arrested Nation Live staffers, editor Anuj Shukla and achor Anshul Kaushik, contended they were “mere employees of the channel”, who had joined a few months ago and had nothing to do with the channel’s ownership pattern. Gupta told TOI, “Anuj joined the channel only two months ago and had not prepared or signed any document related to the channel. For any work done by the channel, its owners/directors are responsible. Both Anuj and Anshul were merely employees.” He too said they will now move the high court for bail. The court said “it was unclear as to which administrative official had granted authority to BR Media to work for Network 10 on rent”. The court order on Anuj’s bail plea reads: “Investigation is on in the issue. The case diary also mentions fraud with some channel employees and issuance of cheques, which bounced due to lack of funds. So far, the memorandum of association and memorandum of article have not been included in the investigation.” On Tuesday, the court of additional district and sessions judge V Nalin Kant Tyagi had ordered that the bail pleas of the trio in the defamation case be accepted and they be granted bail after submission of two sureties of Rs. 40,000 each. Noting that the sections 153 and 505 (1), 505 (2) are scrutinable by a magistrate and sections 153 and 501 are bailable offences, the court had said that the discussion does not seem to cause enmity, hatred and disaffection in the society. The arguments in the second FIR were heard on Wednesday in the court of ADJ (fast track court) Ved Prakash Verma and a copy of the order was issued late Wednesday night. The second FIR states that the inquiry by the assistant director, district information department Meena Biswas found that the “channel had no license or permission from a designated officer for running the channel.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Yoga Day.description: The world marks the fifth edition of International Day of Yoga on June 21, 2019. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hosted the main event in Ranchi and performed yoga along with 18,000 people. It was on September 27, 2014 that PM Modi proposed a dedicated day for Yoga to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). In 2015, the first International Day of Yoga was observed. Here's a look at different yoga styles and its growing popularity worldwide. Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

UT man booked for cheating Ambala reside.description: AMBALA: The district police have booked a Chandigarh resident for allegedly sending a person to the US on someone else's passport. The accused had obtained the passport from the parents of a Class VIII student of DPS, Ambala. The complainant, Gurkirpal Singh of Topkhana Bazaar in Ambala Cantonment, told cops that the accused had fooled him on the pretext of sending his son to Disneyland and NASA in the US. The Ambala police have booked the accused, Chetan Sabharwal of Sector 20D, Chandigarh, under Sections 406 (punishment for criminal breach of trust) and 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). "Sabharwal had organized a camp at my son's school and selected him for a trip to the US. For this, he had demanded Rs 2.3 lakh and his passport. I initially gave him Rs 30,000 as file charges and for the visa. Following this, he sent me a copy of the visa via WhatsApp. The visa was valid for 10 years. However, later, he said that my son will have to wait until December 2016. He kept on delaying and finally in June 2017 told us that my son's passport was stolen from his car. We immediately filed a DDR and applied for a new passport," the complainant said. "On June 11, 2019, we were in the process of boarding our flight to Berlin, where my elder son lives, however, the immigration department at Indira Gandhi International Airport, New Delhi, did not let us board the flight. They told us that my son's passport was already in use by someone in the US. The officials of the immigration department demanded the copy of the DDR, which we provided. Meanwhile, I tried to contact Sabharwal, but he did not respond," Gurkirpal said. "For the last 10 days, I am trying to seek help from departments concerned. My entire family is going through mental stress," he added. Meanwhile, Ambala DSP Munish Sehgal said it was a rare case as he had not encountered anything like this before. "Such type of fraud has not come to my notice in Ambala and this could be one of the rare cases. As per my experience, such frauds exist. We will verify all facts and investigate the case accordingly," he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

It\u2019s now easier to talk about menta.description: At the best of times, mental health is not a topic that lends itself easily to public conversations. The stigma attached to conditions such as depression or anxiety is all too real in India, leaving sufferers despairing of a way out of the darkness. This is where support networks come in, with the offer of a patient and empathetic ear, and (just maybe) the promise of future emotional well-being. Finally, it seems, there’s a window for those who struggle to see the light. Sakshi Virmani reports Hawkers and peddlers swarm the Georgian colonnades of Connaught Place on a busy Sunday evening. Inside Central Park, a group of 15 youngsters huddle together on the dew-drenched grass, unmindful of ardent lovebirds playing peekaboo around them. The session gets underway with an activity in which members are asked to identify a nearby object, something they can relate to. A bespectacled boy picks a bench, someone else chooses a defunct traffic light. At this Offcause meet-up, each of the 15 is being keenly observed by a psychologist, who is helming the hour-long group therapy. Here, you can speak freely about your fears, anxieties and traumas, and, also, share tips on how to get by. The idea is to get everyone talking, to make sure nobody feels left out, by providing a sheltered space and an environment that’s non-judgemental, accommodative and creative. Offcause, for example, lends a hand by encouraging men and women to talk candidly, or to take part in activity-based therapy (painting, dance, improv comedy). More than a few come to listen, some seek succour in the shape of suggestions, yet others draw strength from fellow participants who have emerged from the shadows. “Acknowledging the stigma is the first step, and getting yourself out of the house is another – we self-stigmatise ourselves so much,” claims UK-based Jhilmil Breckenridge, a poet, mental-health activist and founder of Bhor Foundation, an initiative devoted to mental health. Indeed, for the thousands whose days seem perpetually gloomy, an hour or so in the right company might help part the clouds to reveal a ray of sunshine.  LISTENING WITHOUT PREJUDICE Initiatives like Offcause offer a support web for the many overwhelmed by mental health concerns, without the patient having to shell out on a therapist (thus, avoiding the unease of a visit to the psychiatrist). Such collectives comprise individuals whose experiences leave them best suited to help others similarly afflicted. “After I got out of depression, I realised it really helps to talk to somebody who is going through similar issues, as it gives them hope,” admits Mridul Trehan, who credits counseling received by the Delhi Depression Support Group for his recovery. Ujala, a 29-year-old from Jammu, suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and clinical depression. A regular at Offcause meet-ups, Ujala feels that sharing her experiences can be of immense value to fellow sufferers trying to understand the difference between surface and underlying issues. “Personally, I am seeing a psychiatrist and a psychologist for my PTSD and depression, but I love being a part of Offcause — to help others going through various mental disorders,” she says. “You cannot categorise mental illness due to some accident or trigger, it depends on genetics and the way some people’s brains are wired. Some incidents have a ripple effect, they keep playing again and again, which is emotionally consuming,” explains Ujala, who doesn’t just recall incidents, she relives them (like the domestic violence she and her mother have been victims of). For Offcause founder Nikita, it was a causal Instagram update on World Mental Health Day last October that proved the spark. “I asked if people had any stories to share anonymously for the Instagram page I wanted to launch, (and) the response was great – it was surprising to see my closest friends talking about issues they would have never discussed with me on the rare occasions we would meet,” reveals Nikita, who, having left her job just three months earlier, was somewhat at her wit’s end. So, a page was created and the conversations continued. In less than a month, Offcause had its first informal group therapy session. Since then, it has been hosting meet-ups on the third Saturday of every month in Delhi, Gurgaon and Mumbai.  STRIKING THE RIGHT NOTE At an upmarket gastropub in South Delhi, a group of musicians are sharing a laugh over pints of draught beer. They form part of support group Good Vibration, initially launched to discuss problems affecting young musicians, and anybody associated with the industry. Now, anyone can join in, in the monthly meets. Founder Rithika Nayan, a music teacher and certified life coach, commences by talking about anxiety. Soon, the discussion touches on panic attacks, and how best to deal with them. “Scream!” suggests one. “Take a nap!” recommends another, a quick-fix that has everyone nodding in unison. “We millennials are looking for external validation all the time. Blowing things out of proportion in our heads, overthinking and suppressing emotions leads to extreme outbursts. We are never taught how to deal with our emotions intelligently,” explains Rithika to an audience of 12, all absorbed. “Keeping a gratitude journal really helps — counting the small blessings makes a difference,” she offers. According to a 2015-16 survey by Bangalore-based National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences (NIMHANS), 13.7% of India’s general population suffers from a mental ailment. While 150 million Indians are in urgent need of mental health intervention, only 30 million have access to such care. And, according to WHO (World Health Organisation) projections, by 2020 approximately 20% of Indians would be beset by some form of mental illness. Yet, to many in India, mental health still comes with plenty of baggage, and potential loss of face in front of peers. The older generation is reluctant to talk about it and the young think it’s a fad, believes psychologist Dr Ritu Dangwal. She advocates an organised support network. “Support groups are essentially reassurance and reinforcements, more like stopgap arrangements. The groups need to realise that if a person needs extra help, they must guide them to psychiatrists,” she insists. “In India, poor people don’t have the bandwidth to access even basic medical care. But it is heartening to know at least the younger generation is reaching out and saying it’s okay to talk about it.” Dr Dangwal does, however, advise caution. “The tricky part is when everyone starts giving advice. It’s encouraging to have support groups but only to a point — they can address problems at the surface.”  CARE FOR THE CAREGIVERS On a Saturday afternoon last month, a support group of caregivers assembled to discuss family and relationships at Khoj Studios, in the bylanes of Delhi’s Khirki Extension. The Listening Circles provide solace and support not just for those undergoing mental distress, but also for their caregivers, who could be a spouse, parents or children. This support network is moderated by Namarita Kathait, a commissioning editor with a publishing house, and Jhilmil Breckenridge. “We wanted to start a support group that is non-hierarchal, and to get people together in a safe space to have a discourse on mental health,” tells Namarita, 25, who inadvertently became a caregiver for her mother when she was diagnosed with schizophrenia. “I was labelled as the sad girl in school because I did not know how to express what I was going through,” she says, speaking for the many who choose to remain silent. For Jhilmil, it’s important that guidance or advice is not pushed against anyone’s wishes. “People are already vulnerable, we don’t want to force things like meditation and spirituality on them,” she stresses. The next step, says Namarita, is to build ‘listening circles’ with those who have attended the sessions, and to create support groups in their own localities, in colleges and hostels, and among the wider community. “Our ethos is very clear – we are here to listen and we keep it as liberal as possible,” she maintains. “People have the right to speak and not speak, to walk in at any point they want.”  YOU’RE NOT ALONE Then there are youngsters striving to cope with parents who have been diagnosed with a mental illness. It’s this bracket that an upcoming support group network is looking to rally around. Behind the group is Divya Dureja, a counseling psychologist, LGBT activist and TEDx speaker. “If your parent experiences mental illness, it is normal for you to have all kinds of different feelings,” she reasons. “You might not understand why your parents act the way they do. It might be hard to know how to understand your parent, or what to do for them.” Divya believes volunteer caregivers need to be empowered as a first line of defence. “I’ve been building frameworks of mental health support groups that don’t seem to exist in our country,” she explained. “Over the past year, I’ve interacted with over 400 students, primarily studying psychology, at panels, summits and workshops, and (also) those individuals who are looking for resources that are empowering to their mental health.” For, psychological well-being is as critical for the ones who deliver care as for those who receive it. And sanctuary can also be found online. On It’s Ok To Talk, the young can share their innermost thoughts through blogs, poetry, video stories, artwork, even audio recordings. But not only the young. Among the personal accounts on the website is a 58-year-old Gurgaon man’s cry from the heart: ‘Today my heart is brimming painfully with hurt feelings and emotions and there is no one here to share these feelings with or to have a shoulder to cry on little… I have been facing problems linked with depression, schizophrenia and what not since ages now – and with me all my family too…’ Proof that age doesn’t discriminate against the despondent of spirit. It’s Ok To Talk reaches out via digital, social media and on-ground activities, which could include public talks, arts-based events and youth leadership programmes. “Anyone can share stories, of lived experiences of mental health and well-being, and the same will have a tremendous impact on those who may be struggling themselves, and help them realise that they are not alone,” informs Sweta Pal, a member of the Delhi team. “By sharing your own story, you can help inspire other young people that mental health does not need to be shrouded in silence, and it’s ok to talk about it.” Happily, it is becoming easier to talk about mental health, aided by get-togethers that are informal and intimate. And while the fragmented nature of the space means there will always be patients who slip through the cracks, still folks are turning to a growing number of support networks, offering as these do more than a glimmer of hope to the unmoored, the lonely and the vulnerable of India. Trafic police see dip in wrong-side driv.description: GURUGRAM: Traffic police on Wednesday launched a city-wide crackdown on wrong-side driving after it received encouraging public response to their previous drive on June 12. In the two drives, traffic police has booked over 1,000 people and seized 31 vehicles. The cops expressed hope such crackdowns on major traffic violations will create deterrence for habitual offenders. The department claimed both drives were in response to citizens’ suggestions on solving the city’s traffic problems, which was initiated earlier this year. Wednesday’s drive was carried out on 27 hotspots, one more than the previous drive, with Nathupur village the new addition to traffic police’s hotlist. All 27 spots were identified after analysing and mapping public responses. The number of violators caught on Wednesday dropped to 420 from 623 on June 12. Similarly, the number of vehicles impounded fell from 17 to 14. Of the 420 violations, the maximum challans — 58 — were issued near Sheetla Mata Mandir, followed by Sapphire Mall with 43 violations, the stretch between Badshapur and Vatika Chowk with 32 and Hamilton Court road with 30. Sheetla Mata Mandir had also recorded the highest violations during the first drive, though this time, there was a significant dip from 122 violations on June 12. Apart from fining violators, police also seized 14 vehicles — four from Hamilton Court road, three from Sikanderpur metro station, two from Sector 55/56 metro station, and one each from Sapphire Mall, Sheetla Mata Mandir, Rail Vihar road between sectors 44 and 56, Nathupur and Vyapar Kendra road. Speaking to TOI, the department pointed out that the idea of involving citizens in their policies is yielding encouraging dividends. Not only has the feedback mechanism helped the department mitigate traffic-related issues like road safety and vehicular congestion by planning crackdowns, it has also helped them gain confidence of the public in their efforts to address issues raised by them. Riding high on confidence after the success of the two crackdowns, the department is planning to launch more drives in future, which will take up other major violations like red light jumping, under-age driving, drunken driving, to name a few. In total, about 25,000 vehicles have been booked for wrong-side driving since January this year, with the highest number of challans — 6,514 — issued in March. According to traffic police, wrong-side driving is not only one of the city’s major traffic violations, but also a major cause of congestions. Meanwhile, traffic congestion at Sirhaul toll on NH 48 was reported due to breakdown of a vehicle at Rajokri service lane towards Delhi. Gurugram traffic police officials rushed to the spot to clear the jam. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Four caught on camera moving body, booke.description: KARNAL: The police have booked four persons allegedly for killing a youth in Karnal, after they were seen moving the body of 25-year-old Sahil in a CCTV footage. A resident of Muana village in Jind district, Sahil was killed in a PG accommodation of Modal Town in Karnal on the intervening night of June 14 and 15. His family told the police that Sahil was called to Karnal by his friend Prashant on June 14, but after that he did not return. The next morning, they learnt about his death. He was carrying Rs 45,000 with him when he had gone to Karnal, the family said. The police recovered the CCTV footage of the PG accommodation, in which Prashant and three others were seeing shifting Sahil’s body to another room. Kismat Singh, victim’s father and a retired Army man, alleged that Prashant and his three friends had murdered his son for robbing his money. DSP Virender Saini said that a case has been registered under Section 302 against Prashant, a resident of Rojala village in Jind district, and three others on the complaint of Sahil’s father. The body had been handed over to the family after post-mortem examination. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Unitech gets GMDA notice for misusing gr.description: GURUGRAM: GMDA issued a notice to developer Unitech Group on Tuesday for allegedly allowing the use of groundwater for construction activities in Nirvana Country. As per the notice, the developer has given groundwater connections to buildings that are currently under construction or without an occupation certificate, which is not permissible under the norms. According to GMDA officials, they had received a complaint from a Nirvana resident stating that groundwater is being used for construction activities in the township. “We have asked the developer to cut all such connections and submit a report within seven days from the date of the notice,” a senior GMDA official said. A copy of the notice, accessed by TOI, stated that in the wake of water shortage faced by the residents of Gurugram, the developer is directed to disconnect all such connections in conformation with the National Building Code, 2016 and MCG Act, 1994. “We’ve also directed the developer to ensure that all such under-construction buildings under the purview of the Nirvana RWA use water from sewage treatment plants for construction purposes,” the official added. There are around 50 under-construction houses in Nirvana Country. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta King 2019.description: NEW DELHI: Satta Matka is a form of gambling or lottery that had originated before the Independence of India.Originally, the game of Matka gambling involved betting on the opening and closing rates of cotton as transmitted to the Bombay Cotton Exchange from the New York Cotton Exchange, via teleprinters.The modern-day Matka gambling/ Satta King is based on random number selection and betting. The players participating in the Satta Matka game/ gambling are required to choose the right number for winning the game. The player who wins the game becomes Satta King and is rewarded financially. Two of the most famous Matka games are - Kalyan and Worli. The Kalyan Matka gambling was started by Kalyanji Bhagat, a farmer from Gujarat, in 1962 and it ran for all days of the week. Another Matka gambling, New Worli Matka, was started by the Rattan Khatri in 1964 with slight modifications to the rules of the game. Khatri’s Matka ran only five days a week, from Monday to Friday.The modern Matka business is centred around Maharashtra.Some of the terms used in the game and their meaning is given below:    Term Meaning   Matka Matka means earthen pot that were used to draw numbers   Single Any digit between 0 and 9   Jodi/Pair Any pair of two digits between 00 and 99    Patti/Panna Three digit number    Open result / close result Outcome of matka betting   Berij Berij is last digit of jodi's/pair's sum The Google 2018 trends data shows that 'satta' and 'matka' were the top searched words in the Madhya Pradesh state in the year 2018. As per the Google data, 'satta' was the 4th most searched word with a score of 36 and 'matka' came 6th with a score of 23.Any form of Satta Matka gambling is illegal in India.Disclaimer: This content is for reference purpose only and The Times of India claims no ownership of this content. Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. Here is the list of constituencies: Arakkonam, Arani, Chennai Central, Chennai North, Chennai South, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Erode, Kallakurichi, Kancheepuram(SC), Kanyakumari, Karur, Krishnagiri, Madurai, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam(SC), Namakkal Nilgiris(SC), Perambalur, Pollachi, Ramanathapuram, Salem, Sivaganga, Sriperumbudur, Tenkasi(SC), Thanjavur, Theni, Thiruvallur(SC), Thoothukudi, Tiruchirapalli, Tirunelveli, Tiruppur, Tiruvannamalai, Vellore, Villupuram(SC), Virudhunagar, Puducherry(Union Territory) KEY CONSTITUENCIESThe key constutuencies include Sivaganga, Chennai South, Chennai North, Chennai Central, Chidambaram(SC), Coimbatore, Cuddalore, Dharmapuri, Dindigul, Kanyakumari, Karur, Thoothukudi , Nilgiris(SC), Trichy, Vellore amd Arani. Haryana farmers contest water at tail-en.description: TETRI/NINDANA/KHERI (ROHTAK): While chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar and agriculture minister Om Prakash Dhankar leave no opportunity to claim that irrigation water is reaching canal tail-ends, reality appears to be different. Among the farmers who suffer due to non-availability of water at tail end are those from Meham Chaubishi's Nindana, Khattar's native village. While the Meham Minor canal was flowing in full glory on June 16 when this correspondent visited the spot, farmers in villages of Tetri, Kheri and Nindana were using diesal-run tubewell to irrigate their land as the canal by side of their field was lying dry. Talking to TOI, Ramesh Kumar, an aged farmer from Nindana village sitting inside the parched canal at tail-end said that in last five years, not even a drop of water has been seen. "The BJP government makes hollow claim of providing water to tail-end fields from public stages in urban areas to grab the imagination of voters by talking about transforming the lives of farmers. But the reality for farmers like us remains unchanged. The situation is only turning from bad to worse," Kumar added. Holding district irrigation department responsible for the worrisome situation of tail end farmers, 60-year-old farmer said, "We keep suffering at tail end with parched land while farmers in front areas of the canal enjoy stolen water by bribing the officials and using political pressure," he added. Bhoop Singh of Kheri village, who has his two acres at tail-end of Meham minor branch, said that he had heard that farmers commit suicide due to agriculture crisis and he could understand why. "What should we do with dry land. There is no money to spend on diesel-run tubewells. The expense on one acre get multiplied three times. No money to spend on education of kids. No government official or representative is ready to listen to our woes. They dub us liars when we go to tell them non-availability of water at tail end," Singh added. Sandeep Kumar, a young farmer from Nindana village who also has field at Meham Minor tail-end, told TOI that he had complained to irrigation department office and new Rohtak MP Arvind Sharma of water theft from the branch and how they remained deprived of their share of water, but action was still awaited. Rohtak executive engineer (irrigation department) Ram Niwas said that against the demand of 1,875 cusecs, they get only 1450 cusecs water and "farmers at tail-end were bound to suffer". On government claim of providing water till canal ends, he said, "The day gap (between supply and demand) is met, the issue will be resolved." Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

National highways in Ambala record 59% f.description: AMBALA: Ambala roads are proving fatal for the residents. In the past three years 59% of the accidents happened on the National Highways (NHs), reveals the data obtained from the Haryana Vision Zero (HVZ) team. The HVZ is a programme of Haryana government related to road safety. Till May 2019, Ambala district has witnessed 109 fatalities which is equal as compared to the numbers from May 2018. HVZ senior road safety associate Rashit Bajaj said, “Our team has been working on strengthening the infrastructure and increasing road safety in Ambala since three years and we have provided time-to-time reports to the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI). Earlier there were no dividers or separators on the highways which caused fatal crashes and we have continuously pressed for dividing the roads with iron grills and nets to decrease the fatality rate. The 23.1km stretch on NH-44 also famously known as GT road from Mohri to Devinagar toll plaza has recorded 19% of the total fatal accidents in the past three years.” Bajaj said, “In winter, the accidents increas due to foggy weather and since last few years we have been able to keep the number of fatalities stagnant and it has not increased. The maximum fatalities are of two-wheeler riders.” On the other side, Ambala police is continuously running awareness campaigns through its Raahgiri events and also observing ‘zero tolerance day’ against the traffic violators. Ambala DSP Sultan Singh said, “The majority of road accidents happen due to the traffic rule violations and the two-wheeler riders are requested to wear helmets while commuting on the district roads. The department is regularly organising awareness events like Raahgiri and public should support the police by obeying traffic rules.” When questioned about the authenticity of the data obtained from the HVZ team and efforts of the district administration for road safety, Ambala additional deputy commissioner Captain Shakti Singh said, “This data is absolutely valid and it is generated in coordination of the police department. We have been regularly holding review meetings related to road safety and the concerned officials are instructed time and again according to the inputs and requirements.” Most fatalities of two-wheelersAccording to the First Information Report (FIR) data registered in fatal crashes in the last three years, 35% accidents are of two-wheeler riders, 28% of pedestrians, car/jeep/taxi/van contributes 24% and cyclists 6%. There have been 759 fatal crashes in Ambala district, out of which, 59% have happened on NHs, maximum crashes happened on NH-44. 24 black spots identified in AmbalaAccording to the Ministry of Road Transport & Highways (MoRTH), Government of India, road accident black spot on National Highways is a road stretch of about 500m in length where atleast 5 road accidents (involving fatalities/grievous injuries) have took place during the last three calendar years. In Ambala, a total of 24 such black spots have been identified. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Gurugram: Man \u2018specialised\u2019 in.description: GURUGRAM: A notorious criminal, Irshad, member of the Shahid alias Advani gang and wanted in 33 cases, was arrested by the crime branch on Monday night. Cops said the accused is an expert at uprooting ATMs using a pick-up van, taking it to an isolated place and cutting them open with a gas cutter to retrieve the cash. With his arrest, six members — Advani, Amjad, Amitabh, Zullu, Istak and now Irshad — of the seven-man gang have now been put behind bars, and cops said they expect ATM theft cases in the city to come down. Of the 33 cases of ATM theft, loot and snatching against Irshad, 29 are registered at different police stations in Gurugram. Police had announced a Rs 50,000 reward for his arrest. According to police, Shahid Polo is the only gang member at large, that he is on the run and that they are hoping to arrest him soon. The gang has executed a series of ATM thefts in Gurugram and adjoining areas between 2012 and 2018. All members are from Kharkhari village in Mewat, and they have a record of attacking police on several occasions, whenever cops tried to arrest them from their homes. Irshad was arrested by police in connection with an ATM theft in Wazirabad. The case was registered at Sector 53 police station on May 7, and handed over to crime unit of Sector 31. Acting on information, police arrested Irshad from Sohna on Monday. He was produced before court on Tuesday and sent to five-day police custody. “He has been in jail thrice before, and was declared a “proclaimed offender” by court in three cases,” said ACP (crime) Shamsher Singh, adding they are hoping to extract more information during Irshad’s interrogation. The gang specialises in ATM thefts, targeting unmanned ATMs in Gurugram. Police said they used to come to Gurugram in a stolen pick-up van after dark. On reaching their pre-decided target, they would tie the ATM machine with a belt fixed to the pickup van and uproot the machine. They would then load it on the van and drive to an isolated spot, where they would cut open the machine with gas cutter, steal the cash and dump the machine in a lake or pond. Huda City Centre flasher held in Delhi,.description: NEW DELHI: Delhi Police’s special cell has arrested a 25-year-old man who had allegedly flashed at a woman and masturbated on the escalator of Huda City Centre metro station last week. The investigation began after the woman, a 29-year-old who is originally from Delhi but currently lives in Gurugram where she works as a brand manager, tweeted on June 17 about the horror she went through after she had alighted from the metro at the terminal station. In a conversation with TOI, she had also called for measures to make public places more secure for women. The accused has been identified as Gurugram resident Dinesh who, police said, lives in Sushant Lok 2 (Sector 57). He belongs to the Hamirpur area of Uttar Pradesh. Dinesh was nabbed by the special cell from near Rajokri flyover in South Delhi. The woman had identified him in CCTV footage, which Gurugram police had circulated to apprehend the suspect. The special cell got a tip-off about the suspect roaming around air force station near Rajokri and nabbed him. He was handed over to the Gurugram police later in the day. A senior Gurugram police officer said the woman was asked to join the investigation. “She recorded her statement today before the judicial magistrate,” he said. The woman was not aware of the arrest till evening and said she would release a statement only after receiving official word. Police suspect Dinesh is a repeat offender and has misbehaved before with women as well. He is being interrogated. He had allegedly followed the 29-year-old out last Friday as she took the escalator to the station compound around 9.25pm. Sensing something wrong, the woman said she had turned around to find the man standing behind her and masturbating. “I confronted him and slapped him,” she had told TOI on Monday, adding the man, who seemed to be in his mid-20s, had responded with a volley of abuses. She said she also screamed to draw fellow commuters’ attention but no one reacted. “No one came forward, not even the women standing near me,” she had said. “We do not need free rides. We need safety. We want safety which every government has failed to provide despite multiple promises,” the woman had tweeted. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil. Fire audit to identify buildings that fl.description: GURUGRAM: The MCG will soon kick off the second phase of fire safety audit of buildings that have been built without seeking mandatory permissions. After identifying the unauthorised buildings and analysing the conditions under which fire NOCs were issued to them, a report will be shared with higher officials in Chandigarh to decide the future course of action. Newly appointed municipal commissioner Vinay Singh in a meeting with officials of the fire department said the ongoing fire safety audit of buildings (up to five-storey) in municipal limits should be completed within the stipulated time frame. A fire department official, who was present in the meeting, said the audit would be completed by June 26 and as per the commissioner’s directions, the fire department would ensure fire safety measures are followed in these buildings. In the meeting, Singh directed the officials to prepare a list of buildings that are prone to fire accidents and those came up violating the rules. The MCG will investigate how these buildings had managed to get permission from the fire department. The department will seek response of higher authorities if any policy decision could be taken for such structures. On Saturday, MCG had issued an order to conduct a lift and fire safety audit of buildings which have more than five floors, and are more than 15 metres high. Additional municipal commissioner YS Gupta said a third-party auditor will conduct the inspection of these buildings in the city. Inspection will be conducted at all hospitals, hotels, cultural centres, schools, coaching centres, cracker-making units and other commercial centres. Prefer pegs in open areas? Face police a.description: GURUGRAM: Tipplers who prefer to drink in their cars or parks will have to stop that soon if they don’t want to face police action. After receiving several complaints of drunken brawls and nuisance created by those consuming alcohol in open areas, police have launched a drive to tackle the menace on city roads and other open areas. On Wednesday night, around 50 cases were registered against the people for allegedly drinking in open areas. In last six months, around 2,000 cases were registered by police. However, despite frequent police crackdowns, drunken brawls have become common in the city, according to residents. The areas that are frequented by those drinking in public areas include MG Road, Sector 29, DLF-2, Galleria market, Sector 56 market, Palam Vihar, Sushant Lok, Golf Course Road and Southern Peripheral Road (SPR). According to police, those who are caught for drinking in open areas are booked under the Excise Act, and it is the prerogative of the judge to decide the punishment. “This is a bailable offence, and mostly people are let free after paying fine,” said police spokesperson Subhash Boken, adding that cops take these people in preventive custody and produce them before court from where they are released after paying fines and promising good conduct. Police said they have been receiving several complaints from residents about nuisance by people who drink in open areas. Around 260 cases were registered in this month under the Excise Act. “Police are acting against such people and every day some cases are registered,” said Boken, adding most cases are registered at Sadar police station. The trend is blamed on increasing number of liquor shops in the city. “There are liquor vends in every road and street of the city. People start gathering around these vends after 8pm, creating nuisance,” said Sameera Sharma, a resident of Sushant Lok-1, adding that drinking in public areas should be banned. Another resident said drinking at pubs and bars in Gurugram is very costly and no one can afford to visit these outlets regularly. “It is much cheaper to buy a drink in these liquor shops than going to a swanky pub,” said a resident from Sector 56, adding that owners of these vends do not mind allowing customers to drink outside their shops in their cars. Some people find more convenient places like parking lots, open areas and parks to drink. As per the excise norms, drinking is allowed only in bars, ahatas (areas approved by the administration) and hotels. However, vend owners and boozers are flouting norms almost every day. Deputy excise commissioner HC Dahiya said the excise department has come up with the provision of ahatas near liquor vends to deal with such problem. “Drinking in open is not allowed and people have to either go to pubs and bars or to ahatas,” he said. India Pakistan news.description: NEW DELHI/ISLAMABAD: India dismissed on Thursday as "fake news" the suggestion in Pak media that it was looking to resume talks with the hostile neighbour and asserted that there was no dilution of its position that Islamabad needed to take verifiable and irreversible action against terrorism for the dialogue to resume. Responding to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's congratulatory letter after he assumed office for the second time, PM Narendra Modi wrote back on June 12 expressing India's desire to have normal and cooperative relations with all its neighbours, including Pakistan, while stressing that "for this, it is important to build an environment of trust, free of terror, violence and hostility". Foreign minister S Jaishankar also wrote to his Pakistani counterpart S M Qureshi, again only in response to the latter's congratulatory letter, emphasising the need for an atmosphere "free from the shadow of terror and violence". The emphasis on the need for Pakistan to rein in terror as a pre-condition for re-engagement was in keeping with the stand which saw Modi refrain from engaging with Imran Khan at the just-concluded SCO summit in Kyrgyzstan. Yet, the Pakistani media chose to interpret the contents of the letters of Modi and Jaishankar as reflecting India's desire to re-engage. The foreign ministry in Delhi quickly scotched the suggestion. "There was complete distortion and an attempt to peddle fake news (in the way it was reported). The letters only reiterated India's old position that it wants normal and cooperative relations with all countries in South Asia and that it was important to create an environment free of terror and violence for it. There was no mention of any sort of dialogue with Pakistan," said MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar, adding that India will not be fooled by any cosmetic action against terror by Islamabad. Emphasising that both the letters were written in as per the "established diplomatic practice", Kumar said: "In their messages, they have highlighted that India seeks normal and cooperative relations with all neighbours, including Pakistan." In his letter, Modi had said that India remained committed to operationalising early an "all-year-round" Kartarpur corridor. Touching upon it, Kumar said India had already held three technical-level discussions with Pakistan and was currently awaiting clarification from Islamabad over a few issues it had raised. Puzzlingly, later in the evening, Pakistan's foreign ministry, which had kept quiet through the day, also sought to play down the speculation about the import of the letters. While responding to a question, the spokesperson said, "It was an established practice for the leadership to congratulate new office holders and for them to respond." "Pakistan's position on the way forward in relations with India was clear and well-known and did not require repetition," said the spokesperson, adding that the "vision of peace, progress and prosperity of South Asia could be advanced by peacefully resolving all outstanding disputes, including Jammu & Kashmir, and moving away from dynamic of confrontation to cooperation". Earlier in the day, sources in the Pakistan foreign office had said that Modi and Jaishankar had responded positively to recent letters from their Pakistani counterparts by conveying New Delhi's desire to engage with all countries, including Pakistan, for elimination of terrorism and prosperity of the region. "India has always prioritised peace and human development, and sought to maintain cordial relations with all regional powers," Modi and Jaishankar maintained, according to FO sources. Both leaders, according to FO sources, called for special attention on elimination of terrorism in the region and said the issue must be a core focus in all future talks. They have also appreciated sentiments from Pakistan in their letters, the FO sources added. Modi's letter was in response to a congratulatory letter from Khan in which he had underscored Pakistan's vision of working for "durable peace and stability in South Asia with peaceful resolution of all outstanding disputes, including J&K". Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Haryana kicks off prepaid power meter pr.description: JIND: The electricity department of Haryana has started installing smart prepaid meters in four out of 22 districts as a pilot project and later entire state will be covered, Shatrujeet Kapur, chairman-cum-managing director (CMD) of the department has said. The state government introduced prepaid smart meters, on the lines of prepaid mobile phones, in view of the hefty outstanding of the electricity department on consumers and to streamline consumption of power. A smart meter costs Rs 6,000, which would be provided free of cost to the consumers, said an official. Kapur said the department has bought 10 lakh smart meters for the four districts of Gurugram, Faridabad, Panchkula and Panipat, and the work to install these meters have already started. "After installation of these meters, line loss of power would decrease and consumers would be able to get power on prepaid and postpaid basis. Then people would be able to recharge their meters according to their requirement," he said. The CMD said that the process for calling a tender to purchase 15 lakh meters for the next phase has been initiated and Jind would be covered in that phase. Last year, Jind district was the biggest defaulter of power bills worth Rs 1,500 crore, of which Rs 1,000 crore has now been settled under the government scheme and Rs 500 crore is yet to be recovered from this district. Once the smart meters are installed, there would be no issue of pending bills, as the department would get the payment in advance. As per current practice, the bills are generated after two months and it takes another month to recover the billed amount. Pending bills are a huge issue for the department. Talking to TOI, V P Thakral, the XEN monitoring Dakshin Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam (DHBVN), said that an amount of Rs 3,400 crore is outstanding on the consumers of 12 districts of the state and around Rs 2,500 crore should be pending of the Uttar Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam, which covers 10 districts. "After installing these meters, the bill outstanding issue would vanished completely, as it would be disconnected if not recharged in advance," he said. The new concept would work on the lines of a prepaid mobile phone, as one would require to recharge to avail the facility and the department would not need to send an employee for taking meter readings, he noted. Yogi Adityanath.description: VARANASI: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath slammed Congress president Rahul Gandhi for suddenly showing concern for the poor and asked why he didn’t ensure a minimum income scheme for them during Congress-led UPA regime when his mother Sonia Gandhi acted as ‘super prime minister’ and had a say in everything. Targeting Congress announcement of minimum income scheme for poor on coming to power, Yogi said, “Congress led UPA was in power in Centre from 2004 to 2014. Everybody knows how Rahul and his mother (Sonia Gandhi) were influential in UPA regime. However, in UPA’s 10-year regime Congress never showed the kind of sympathy for poor, unemployed, farmers and women of country like it is showing now for Pakistan.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. From online to the library: When kids sw.description: On a hot June afternoon, sisters Pooja, 14, and Kajal, 13, make their way through the narrow lanes of Sikanderpur village, rushing past water tankers and bikes, to volunteer at the Community Library Project, in a Gurugram beyond the malls and highrises. Every day, these teen siblings, pupils of the government senior secondary school in Chakkarpur, confidently wear the badge of student counsellors, while also helping in member outreach through community walks. The library – free, open to all, and stocking a wide variety of books – presents a safe learning space for those who do not have access to literature. It has 1,100 members, of which 600 are active. Shubha, a staff member here, calls this their library movement. “Once other citizens realise the importance of libraries, there will be more of them, and we are demonstrating it through our models,” she tells TOI. So, there’s Manisha, 11, who, recalls Shubha, would initially flip through books and admire illustrations. A year later, she has finished the Hindi translations of six of the Harry Potter series. And Kajal, who trains in a parlour before visiting the library. She wants to become a librarian when she grows up. Mohsin, 16, is another promising child, who yearns to be a cop when he’s old enough – and, also, be useful around the library on his free Sundays. “I used to while away my summer holidays but now I feel I am learning more geography and history,” shares an eager Mohsin, whose mother works as a domestic help. Tech doesn’t have the touchAt a time when millennials and kids are plugged into their smartphones and tablets, the space for libraries, both intellectually and physically, is shrinking. But seeing the success of Treasure Trove, you wouldn’t think so. Recently, this quaint library, tucked into a basement of a daycare centre to the south of Gurugram, completed nine years. Quirky quotes and colourful posters welcome you to a paradise for the young bibliophile, which has hosted storytelling sessions with popular children’s writer Jeeva Raghunath (who pioneered the storytelling movement in Tamil Nadu) and South African storyteller Bongiswa Kotta Ramushwana. “When we moved from Bangalore to Gurugram 10 years back, there was no children’s library here. My daughter loved reading books and my son loved solving jigsaw puzzles. I would buy books but they would finish it in a day or two – that is when I conceived the idea of a library,” says founder Arvinda Bhatia. “You can order books online but there are so many new authors who are not read because they are not suggested online – that is where we come into the picture, (by) suggesting you explore a new book,” she adds. Bhatia remembers a seven-year-old Akshat Gupta, who would cram even the smallest details and conversations while reading at Treasure Trove. He would go on to write seven books in a span of three years. Akshat’s works are given pride of place at the library where he started reading. You can bond with a bookAcross the road is another school library, also accessible to everyone, which houses an eclectic collection for kids between the ages of two and 12 (from ‘Why Mosquitoes Buzz in People’s Ears’ by Oliver Jeffers to Julia Donaldson’s ‘The Gruffalo’). The stock at Bookhive, running since 2014, consists of titles the husband-wife duo of Ajay and Ashima Chawla would handpick from their travels. Both developed a love of reading and storytelling because of their son (now in college). “Kindle, iPad or any digital media cannot replace the actual touch and feel of a book,” Ashima insists. “It’s not just having a collection of books but having the right kind of books – Oliver Jeffers’ ‘The Day the Crayons Quit’ happens to be the favourite among children of 3-4 years of age,” she reveals, mentioning, proudly, that her most devoted readers are the class-I and class-II children who have finished more than 200 books. The pair recommends other reads by figuring out the interests of their young members. “The level of customisation is missing when one browses books online from sponsored suggestions – for instance, how many of us knew the ‘Queen of Pop’ Madonna is also a children’s book writer?” asks Ajay, pertinently. Yet, even online libraries like Bookpal and Iloveread have their patrons, because of the convenience they offer. “Since everything is far off in the city, and there’s a lack of good bookstores, parents prefer home delivery of books to introduce their children to the joy of reading,” says Shefali Malhotra of Iloveread, adding, “We are happy to send extra books for parents too.” These volunteers, then, are ensuring that at a time when webpages dominate, the charm of the printed word doesn’t fade among Generation Next. And it is libraries that are pushing back against the tech tide. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

To ease commute, GMDA plans traffic ligh.description: GURUGRAM: In order to ease traffic woes at two of the city’s busiest junctions, Hero Honda Chowk and MDI Chowk, GMDA has invited bids for the installation of traffic lights at these places. However, with two flyovers being recently developed at these intersections, the need for traffic lights raises a question over the administration’s planning at the initial stage. At Hero Honda Chowk, an underpass and a flyover, built at a cost of Rs 138 crore, have eased problems for long-route traffic. “The traffic is smooth while going to or coming from Manesar, but taking a turn towards Sector 10 under the flyover is still cumbersome due to merging vehicles and non-availability of signals,” said Aman Chawla, a city resident. Traffic experts say while the underpass and the flyover have helped in reducing congestion, there are still issues at Hero Honda Chowk due to the movement of vehicles in multiple directions. “As per my understanding, the traffic lights are being installed to streamline the traffic at the junction, which still sees some haphazard movement,” said Sewa Ram of School of Planning and Architecture. The situation is worst at MDI Chowk. According to MCG sources, the original plan was to build a flyover for traffic coming from Atul Katria Chowk and going towards Signature Towers. However, the plan was later tweaked and the flyover was instead built for the traffic coming from Sukhrali and going towards Atul Kataria Chowk. The last-minute changes at the junction have made the situation worse, causing the need for a traffic signal at the junction. “A study showed that maximum traffic flows from Atul Kataria Chowk towards Signature Towers. This is because a large number of people from Old Gurugram coming towards New Gurugram use Atul Kataria Chowk and MDI Chowk. That was the reason why it was decided to build the flyover in that direction but later on, on the instruction of some bureaucrats, the direction was changed,” said a senior MCG official. Despite repeated attempts, GMDA’s mobility chief RK Gandhi could not be contacted. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Two-year-old female leopard electrocuted.description: GURUGRAM: A two-year-old female leopard died due to electrocution in Mandawar village near Gurugram on Thursday morning. Panic gripped the villagers when they found the leopard hanging from high-tension wires entangled over a tree around 8am. Locals informed the forest department. The forest department officials reached the spot at 9am and the carcass was taken for post mortem examination. “It is so unfortunate that lineman didn’t lop such a life-threatening tree. In such cases, permission is always given by the forest department. However, the department’s permission was not sought,” said a senior wildlife official. He added that the reason for the death was clearly electrocution, but a detailed report will be released soon. BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. Two weeks left, 1,518 apply for Gurugram.description: By: Ipsita Pati GURUGRAM: Gurugram University (GU) is preparing to welcome 720 students this academic session With just two more weeks left before completion of the admission session at the university on July 2, a total of 1,518 applicants have applied for 22 courses so far. The university is also introducing 11 new courses this session. With the new addition, its total strength will be 1,240 students. Last year, GU had received a total of around 1,600 applications. University officials are hoping that they will get more applicants this academic session, the admissions to which will be closed on July 2. “We’ve so far received 1,518 applications for 720 seats. We’ve increased the number of seats and courses this year. The entire application process is also online. For humanities stream, students are advised to apply through Kurukshetra University and for science stream, students should apply through Maharshi Dayanand University,” a university spokesperson said. As GU has a centralised procedure for admission, students have to go through an entrance test. “Students are admitted to the university on the basis on merit,” a senior professor from the law faculty said. New courses introduced this year include MA (journalism and mass communication), MPharma, Master of physiotherapy, Master of social science, MSc (neuroscience), MSc (actuarial science), MA (administration) and MA (economics), LLM, post-graduate (PG) diploma in corporate law and PG diploma in labour law. In April 2017, the Haryana cabinet had approved a Bill to set up a state university in Gurugram, which has been a long-standing demand of students of the area, who have to travel either to Delhi or other cities for higher education. The university’s own campus is not yet completed. It operates out of the campus of Rao Tularam College of Science and Commerce in Sector 51. With GU’s own campus in Sector 85 still under construction, it is expected to take another two years, and around Rs 700 crore, for it to become fully functional. MCG focuses on waste to better swachh ra.description: GURUGRAM: MCG on Wednesday discussed various parameters that can decide the ranking of a city in the Swachh Survekshan Survey 2020, in order to upgrade Gurugram’s position in the national list. Gurugram was ranked 85 in the 2019 survey, and 105 in 2018. At the meeting, MCG joint commissioners Hariom Atri and Inderjit Kulharia discussed ways by which the sanitation department can overcome hurdles it faces. Apart from making the city open-defecation free, MCG officials also stressed on segregation of garbage and monitoring of waste generators. They also discussed how to process the accumulated garbage at the existing site in Bandhwari. All sanitation officials were advised to spread awareness on waste segregation in all colonies and plotted societies. “The door-to-door garbage collection programme, registering informal waste pickers, ban of single-use plastic, new waste processing facility, remediation of existing dump sites, are some of the prerequisites to gain Swachh Survekshan points, so we’re concentrating on waste collection and processing. Also, this year there’s 10% extra for educating people about cleanliness,” said a senior MCG official. Sanitation officers were directed to map out the city’s perennially filthy areas, where cleanliness drives can be carried out in the next few months. Recently, MCG commissioner Vinay Singh issued a directive to impose fines on residents who failed to segregate wet and dry waste. This year, the survey will be decided by evaluating a city’s performance in the three quarters left — April to June, July to September, October to December. The parameters include capacity building, collection and transportation of solid waste, processing and disposal of waste, sustainable sanitation and information, education and communication regarding waste, all of which carry different maximum points which a city can score by fulfilling the targets.
